text:
When you build "buildbin" the install script at the end of the build process
copies all of the PDB files along with EXE and SO modules into the /bin and
/modules directories.
creator: jerrybaker@attbi.com
wrowe@apache.org
text:
This is "by design".  Typical users won't be building from sources, while
  developers will.  Developers building Apache and testing their changes need
  these files to help debug the problems that ensue.  Developers who want 
  to later diagnose crash dumps must also archive these symbols to load them
  into the debugger with a crash dump.  Leave them, remove them or archive 
  them as appropriate to your case.

  This is similar to the Unix case, where Apache will not strip binaries of
  whatever level of debugging information which is compiled into the programs.

So you can debug a release build? If so, what's the point of a debug build? Just
curious.
creator: apache-bugzilla@bakerweb.biz

text: There's no debug build. That's it.
creator: nd@perlig.de
apache-bugzilla@bakerweb.biz
text:
I'm sorry for spamming this bug, but now I'm really confused. You mean the
release builds of Apache are filled up with debug symbols and debug code? If so,
how do you build a "true" optimized copy? And, if there is no "debug build" why
does the makefile have debug options?:

# Targets are:
#   _apacher   - build Apache in Release mode
#   _apached   - build Apache in Debug mode
#   installr   - build and install a Release build
#   installd   - build and install a Debug build
#   clean      - remove (most) generated files
#   _cleanr    - remove (most) files generated by a Release build
#   _cleand    - remove (most) files generated by a Debug build

Ah, seems like a slight misunderstanding. I meant, that we don't distribute
debug builds. Thatwhy the external symbol files. The debug stuff should include
the symbols within the code itself. Hope it's all clear now :-)
creator: nd@perlig.de
